column6: Purpose
column9: Description

column6: Calf tightness, knee pain, runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Stand in front of a wall with both hands resting at shoulder level on the wall. 2) Place your left leg in front taking most of your body weight on this leg. 3) Place the right leg stretched far out behind you keeping the knee straight and only putting the ball of the foot on the ground. 4) Slowly bend the left knee and move your pelvis forward towards the wall. 5) Keeping the right knee straight gently push the right heel downwards until you feel a mild stretch high up in the calf. 6) Hold for 20-30 seconds, repeat x2 each sideYou can vary this stretch by rotating the heel out to the left of the toes and also to the right of the toes to feel the stretch in the outer and inner muscle fibres.

column6: Calf tightness, knee pain, runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Stand in front of a wall with both hands resting at shoulder level on the wall. 2) Place your right leg in front taking most of your body weight on this leg. 3) Place the left leg stretched far out behind you keeping the knee straight and only putting the ball of the foot on the ground. 4) Slowly bend the right knee and move your pelvis forward towards the wall. 5) Bend the left knee until you feel a stretch lower down in the calf (heel can lift off the ground) . 6) Hold for 20-30 seconds, repeat x2 each side.

column6: Tight inner thighs, runners, walkers, most sports
column9: To stretch the right side: 1) Kneel on the ground and bring your right leg out straight  to the side so that the inside of your right foot is contacting the ground. 2) Push your leg down towards the ground, you should feel a stretch on the upper inner thigh. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice both sides.

column6: Tight inner thighs, runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Lie on the floor with your buttocks close to the wall and your legs up the wall. 2) Keeping your knees straight slowly slide your legs against the wall and down the side until you feel a stretch. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice.

column6: Tight inner thighs, runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Sit on the floor with both legs spread apart with your knees straight. 2) Tilt your pelvis forward which should increase the stretch. 3) Keep a small curve in your lumbar spine and lean forward gently to increase the stretch. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds, repeat twice.

column6: Strengthening the quads for knee instability / weakness, walkers, runners
column9: 1)Tie a Resistance Band around the leg of a chair or table that you will be sitting on and then to your ankle (make sure the stool / chair is tall enough so your feet do not hit the ground)2)Sit up straight, slowly straighten your leg and then slowly flex back down, repeat 10 times both sides.3)Repeat 3 sets with 20 or so seconds break between each set

column6: Strengthening the hamstrings for knee instability / weakness, walkers, runners
column9: 1) Lie face down on a mat with a resistance band tied around the ankle and the opposing end tied to a table leg firmly. 2) Rest your forehead on your folded arms. 3) Try and keep a neutral spine* with pelvis stabilised - don't allow the lower back to over extend (keep it as still as possible). 4) Breathe in and as your breathe out bring your ankle towards your buttocks feeling the muscles in the back of the leg working. 5) Breathe in returning your leg back down. 6) Repeat 10 times, break for 20 or so seconds and repeat again 10 times. 7) Repeat other side. (*See related exercises)

column2: Knee extensions over foam roller / towel
column6: Strengthening the quads for knee instability / weakness, walkers, runners
column9: 1) Lie on your back with a foam roller under your knees or sitting. 2) Gently and slowly straighten your right leg into full extension and then flex back down to the foam roller. 3) Repeat 10 times. 4) Repeat on the left side.

column6: Strengthening VMO helps weakness and knee instability, knee pain, runners, walkers who experience instability
column9: 1)Sitting down on the floor with a rolled up towel / foam roller under 1 knee2)Straighten out leg from this slightly flexed position (pushing back of knee into towel)3)Hold this position for 5 seconds (feel VMO contract by pressing fingers into inner part of quad)4)Repeat x 10

column6: Hip mobility and leg strength
column9: 1) Stand with your feet hip width apart, then take a step out to the side. 2) Your feet should be at a 45 degree angle. 3) Using your arms to balance, squat down fully and if possible trying to keep your feet flat on the floor. 4) Your elbows can be resting on your inner thighs and gently pushing out to increase the stretch in your inner thighs. 5) Try to hold for 30-60 seconds and build up to 2 minutes (there should be a strong stretch but no hip or knee pain).

column3: Calf (lower leg) stretch using foam roller
column6: Tight calves, runners, walkers
column9: 1) Sitting with the foam roller under both your calves. 2) Using both arms stabilising behind you on the ground, lift your hips up increasing the weight / pressure through the calves. 3) Using your arm and shoulder strength roll your calves up and down the foam roller. 4) Repeat 10-15 times or until the tenderness or tightness starts to reduce (30-60 seconds).

column3: Hamstring (back of thigh) stretch using foam roller
column6: Tight hamstrings, runners, walkers
column9: 1) Sitting with the foam roller under both your hamstrings. 2) Using both arms stabilising behind you on the ground, lift your hips up increasing the weight / pressure through the hamstrings. 3) Using your arm and shoulder strength roll your hamstrings up and down the foam roller. 4) Repeat 10-15 times or until the tenderness or tightness starts to reduce (30-60 seconds)

column6: Tight ITB, knee pain due to tight ITB, runners, walkers
column9: 1) Lie with your left hip on the foam roller and your left leg out straight. 2) Your arms are straight directly under both your shoulders supporting your body weight. 3) Place your right leg over your left bent and foot contacting the ground and stabilising. 4) Roll your left outer leg (ITB) up and down the foam roller adjusting the amount of weight you put through depending on how tender the area is. 5) Try to repeat 10-15 times depending on tenderness (30-60 seconds)

column6: To strengthen quads, walkers, runners, improve core strength
column9: 1) Sitting tall on a Swiss ball with both feet planted firmly on the ground. 2) Draw your shoulders down and activate core*. 3) Straighten out your right leg feeling your quads tighten / activate (muscles at the front of your leg) and then return to the start position. 4) Repeat 10-15 times. 5) Repeat other side. (*See related exercises)

column3: Hamstring strengthening (back thigh muscles) using a Swiss Ball
column6: To strengthen the hamstrings, improving knee mobility after injury
column9: 1) Lying face down on a Swiss ball with both hands on the floor and feet  contacting the floor. 2)Try to engage your core* and find neutral spine* (not allowing your lower back to dip). 3) Flex your right leg (bending at the knee) and straighten out again. 4) Repeat 10-15 times. 5) Repeat on the other leg. (*See 'neutral spine and core' under programs)

column3: Calf raises using a Swiss Ball
column6: To strengthen the calves, walkers, runners
column9: 1) Standing against a wall with the Swiss ball behind your back and leaning back slightly into the ball. 2) Draw your shoulders down and engage your core*. 3) Lift up onto both tippy toes and then slowly lower back down. 4) Repeat 10-15 times. 5) Rest for 30 seconds and repeat. (*See related exercises)

column6: To strengthen hips / legs, runners, walkers, other sports
column9: 1) Standing tall, core* engaged, shoulders draw down, hands on hips for balance if needed. 2) Take a step to the side and squat making sure your knee tracks directly over your ankle. 3) Bring the leg back to the starting position. 4) Repeat 10-15 times. 5) Repeat other leg. (*See related exercises)

column6: To strengthen hips/ legs, improve balance and proprioception, runners,  walkers, other sports.
column9: 1) Standing tall, core* engaged, shoulders draw down, hands on hips for balance if needed. 2)Lift one leg off the floor bending at knee. 3) Slowly lower down bending your other knee and then slowly straighten up again trying to track the knee directly over the ankle. 4) Repeat 10 times each leg. (*See related exercises)

column6: To strengthen hips/ legs, improve balance and proprioception, runners,  walkers, other sports.
column9: 1)  Place a sturdy chair against a wall. 2) Stand in front of the chair, engage your core* and draw your shoulders down. 3) Step up onto the chair with your left leg firmly planting the foot and then follow with your right leg stepping onto the chair. 4) Lower you left leg down to the ground and follow with the right leg. 5) Repeat 10-15 times each side. 6) Concentrate on stabilising your hips so that you don't sway too much to either side with the movement. (*See related exercises)

column6: To strengthen hips/ legs, improve balance and proprioception, runners,  walkers, other sports.
column9: 1)  Place a sturdy chair against a wall. 2) Stand in front of the chair, engage your core* and draw your shoulders down. 3) Step up onto the chair with your right leg firmly planting the foot and then follow with your left leg bringing your left knee up. 4) Lower you left leg down to the ground gently and then bring it straight back up again - the movement should be fluid. 5) Repeat 10-15 times each side. 6) Concentrate on stabilising your hips so that you don't sway too much to either side with the movement. (*See related exercises)

column6: Tight calves, runners, walkers
column9: 1) Come onto all fours on the ground with hands flat on the floor under your shoulders. 2) Straighten both legs so that they are straight out behind you. 2) Bend one knee in at the same time pushing the other foot flat to the ground increasing and feeling the stretch in that leg. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat the for the other leg. 5) Then slowly repeat the action of flexing (bending) one knee, then the other in a pedal like motion for 10-15 repetitions.

column6: To strengthen quads, walkers, runners, after knee injury
column9: 1)Place a foam roller or larger rolled up towel under knee 2) Activate core* and make sure pelvis is stable.3)Slowly straighten knee and feel the quadriceps contracting4)Hold for 5 seconds and then slowly lower back down5)Repeat 10 times. (*See related exercises)

column6: Post knee operation, knee injury
column9: 1) Sit on a chair, keep your foot flat on the ground with the toes directly in front of the heel. 2) Have the outside of the base of the fifth toe resting against something that will not move e.g.. the leg of a table. 3) Without lifting the foot too far off the ground, push the foot out against the leg of the table .4) Hold for five seconds. Relax. 5) Repeat 10-15 times.

column6: Post knee operation, knee injury
column9: 1) Sit on a chair, keep your foot flat on the ground with the toes directly in front of the heel. 2) Have the base of the big toe resting against the leg of a table. 3)Push the foot in against the table.  (as the knee gets stronger you can increase the angle of the foot to the leg). 4) Hold for five seconds. Relax. 5) Repeat 10-15 times.

column6: Post knee operation, knee injury, knee stiffness or pain
column9: 1) Sitting down on the ground with both knees out straight and hands resting for support just behind you or lying down. 2) Keeping your foot on the ground, slide your heel in towards your buttocks slowly and then straighten out again. 3) Repeat 10 times. 4) Repeat other leg if required.

column6: VMO weakness, knee pain / instability
column9: 1) Sitting tall in a chair with both hips and knees flexed at 90 degrees and feet flat on the floor. 2) Place your fingers on the inner side of your knee (inner quadriceps). 3) Try to contract your quadriceps by pulling your knee cap up and feeling the muscle under your fingers contract, the sensation can be subtle and may take some practising. 4) Hold for 3 seconds and release. 5) Repeat 10-20 times.

column6: VMO weakness, knee pain / instability
column9: 1) Standing tall with feet hip width apart. 2) Step your right foot out in front of your left (not wide just a comfortable step) with your toes slightly pointing out to the side at an angle. 3) Bend slightly at the knee and then extend up again concentrating on contracting the quadriceps and in particular the muscle fibres on the inside of the thigh just above the knee. 4) Make sure your knee is tracking directly over your ankle. 5) If necessary to start, place your fingers on the inside of your knee to feel the muscles contract. 6) Repeat 10-15 times and repeat other side if necessary.

column2: VMO strengthening step down and up
column3: VMO - inner quadriceps strengthening (on a step)
column6: VMO weakness, knee pain / instability
column9: 1) Standing on the edge of a step or ledge with your left foot turned slightly out at an angle. 2) Step your right foot down slightly touching gently off the bottom and step the leg back up again. 3) You are working the left VMO, make sure you can feel the muscles on the inner thigh above the knee contracting as you step down and up again. 4) Repeat 10-15 times and other side if necessary.

column6: Runners, walkers, cyclists
column7: It is difficult to isolate a stretch to the popliteus but stretching the hamstrings will help to stretch the popliteus. Responds well to direct manual therapy by a qualified practitioner. See Stretches: 6, 7, 8

column6: Post ankle / leg injury, stimulate proprioception
column9: 1) Stand on one leg, lifting the other leg up, and hold for up to a minute (as long as you can without losing balance). 2) Repeat 3 times. 3) When this becomes easy you can increase the challenge by closing your eyes and repeating the same exercise. 4) Increasing difficulty again, coming up onto tip toes.

column6: To stimulate proprioception / neural connections between the feet and brain
column9: 1) Walk on the beach barefoot! Very good for your proprioception and nerve endings in your feet.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, knee pain
column9: 1) Kneel down on the ground and bring your right leg out to the side with your knee straight. 2) Drop your right hip to the floor until your feel a stretch up the inner thigh. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice each side.

column3: Back of thigh stretch (lying on back)
column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Lie on your back holding a towel or piece of strong resistance band. 2) Bend up your right knee and lift your leg placing the towel around your foot and holding onto each end with your hands. 3) Pull your right leg up in towards your chest until you feel a stretch up the back of your leg. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice both sides.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Kneel on the ground - place a pillow under your left knee if you have sensitive knees. 2) Straighten out your right leg in front of you. 3) Keep your lumbar curve (concavity) and lean forward from your pelvis (not lower back). 3) Feel a stretch up the back of the leg, hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice each side.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, lower back pain
column9: 1) Standing, straighten out your right leg with your heel on the ground. 2) Putting your weight on your left side bend your left knee and lean over your right leg until your feel a stretch up the back of your leg. 3) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 4) Repeat twice each side.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Standing tall, bend your right knee and reach behind with your right arm to hold your right foot. 2) Draw your shoulders down and find neutral spine* (do not tilt forward). 3) Gently pull your foot into your buttocks until you feel a stretch up the front of your right thigh. 4) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 5) Repeat twice each side. (*See 'neutral spine and core' under programs)

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports
column9: To stretch your right quad: 1) Kneel down on the ground placing a pillow under your right knee if required and lunge your left leg out in front so that your knee is at a right angle (hold onto a chair for support if needed). 2) Keep your back straight (neutral spine*) and do not twist to the side.3) Lunge forward on your back leg slightly and then tuck your tailbone under (curling your pubic bone up towards the ceiling) until you should feel a stretch up the front of your back leg (right), to increase the stretch you can hold onto your right foot. 4) Make sure your knee does not come over your ankle when you lunge forward. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds and repeat twice each side. (*See 'neutral spine and core' under programs)

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports
column9: 1) Lie on your right side with your head resting on your right arm and right knee bent for stability. 2) Bend your left knee and hold onto your left foot with your left hand. 3) Stabilise your pelvis (don't allow it to move forward) - all the movement should come from your leg. 4) Pull your left leg back until you feel a stretch up the front of the right thigh. 5) Hold for 20-30 seconds. 6) Repeat twice each side.

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, knee weakness
column9: 1) Standing tall with feet hip width apart. 2) Place the Swiss Ball behind you against a wall in the small of your lower back. 3) Draw your shoulders down, engage your core* and squat down as if you are going to sit down in a chair. 4) Your knees travel directly in line with your ankles. 5) Your arms can straighten out in front as you squat to help balance you.6) Repeat 10-15 times. (*See 'neutral spine and core' under programs)

column6: Runners, walkers, most sports, hip weakness
column9: 1) Standing tall with arms out front for balance and feet hip width or a little wider. 2) Try to concentrate on not leaning forward or back, weight should be through the mid to forefoot. 3) Squat down as far as you can, feet as flat as possible - you should feel no pain in hips, knees or ankles. 4) Repeat 10-15 times.
